tossups.question: Francesco Tiradritti enraged a leading scholar of this period when he announced with little evidence that a painting of six geese from this period might be a fake. One building created during this period used a sand foundation for its outer layers, leading those layers to collapse in a heap around it. During this period, a sun temple at Abusir was commissioned by Userkaf. During this period, the text that would become the Book of Coming Forth by Day was inscribed directly onto tomb walls. This period began to decline when the nomarchs gained power under the reign of Pepi II. The legendary architect Imhotep lived in this period, during which he designed a monument consisting of six progressively smaller mastabas, the Step Pyramid of Pharaoh Djoser. The Great Pyramids of Egypt were built during this kingdom. For 10 points, name this earliest kingdom of Ancient Egypt.
tossups.answer: Old Kingdom [accept just Old after “kingdom”]  <History World - French>

tossups.question: In one novel from this country, the title character gains a nickname after escaping from forced labor with the army with a herd of stolen camels. Another character from this country is nicknamed “the paraffin lamp” because a ringworm scar on his head turns red when he's angry. In one short story collection from this country, the narrator reminisces about fishing with his grandfather after seeing a fiberglass fishing rod in a shop window. One character from this country considers events such as getting attacked by a dog while stealing turnips and being executed “moral victories”. Another character from this country sees the words “eat people” written in various classical texts. The novels Rickshaw Boy and Red Sorghum are set in this country, as are a non-Gogol “A Madman's Diary” and The True Story of Ah Q. For 10 points, name this country home to authors such as Lao She, Mo Yan, Gao Xingjian, and Lu Xun.
tossups.answer: People's Republic of China [Accept Zhongguo Renmin Yinhang, Republic of China, Qing Empire]  <Literature World - Myers>

tossups.question: A Stanley Schacter experiment on anxiety tested if people expecting this action would seek out the company of others. A year before the Stanford Prison Experiment, Philip Zimbardo conducted an experiment on an exclusively female sample of participants, in which subjects who wore hoods over their faces and were denied nametags caused this experience with twice the intensity of identifiable peers. This action was performed randomly on dogs in a “shuttle box” by Martin Seligman, who created the “learned helplessness” theory of depression as a result. This activity was simulated by people who placed an ad for a memory study and demanded that “teachers” perform this activity on “learners” in the Milgram obedience experiment. For 10 points, name this experience which the brain might be subjected to in a radical “therapy.”
tossups.answer: electric shocks [or being shocked; or being electrocuted or word forms]  <Social Science Psychology - Weiner>

tossups.question: A set of m of these quantities is listed in ascending order, and the kth largest is compared to k over m times another quantity, in the Benjamini-Hochberg procedure. Negative two times the sum of the logarithms of a set of these quantities is analyzed in a method of meta-analysis named for Fisher. An upper bound on a set of m of these quantities is divided by m in a technique that applies the union bound to control the FWER, which is the Bonferroni correction. By definition, these quantities are uniformly distributed under H0 (H sub zero). The multiple comparisons problem can lead to the so-called “hacking” of these quantities, whose size is often depicted using one, two, or three asterisks when reporting the results of a hypothesis test. For 10 points, name these quantities whose size relative to the significance level determines whether the null hypothesis is rejected.
tossups.answer: p-value [or asymptotic significance; or probability value; do not accept or prompt on “significance” or “significance level”]  <Science Math - Morrison>

tossups.question: This poet described how the “flames” of those “With whom the infant Love yet plays...do lose their light, / Like meteors of a summer's night” in the poem “The Unfortunate Lover.” The title creatures “portend / No war nor prince's funeral” and possess an “officious flame” in a poem by this author that calls them “country comets” and “living lamps.” This poet wrote “Tis madness to resist or blame / The force of angry Heaven's flame” after describing how the title figure “like the three-fork'd lightning” destroyed Caesar; that “restless” character “could not cease / In the inglorious arts of peace.” This poet wrote of “deserts of vast eternity” in a poem whose speaker describes the growth of his “vegetable love.” For 10 points, “An Horatian Ode upon Cromwell's Return from Ireland” was written by which poet, who described “Time's wingèd chariot hurrying near” in “To His Coy Mistress?”
tossups.answer: Andrew Marvell <Literature British Non-Shakespeare - Shanmugam>

tossups.question: In the second movement of this symphony, the first violins spell out the tonic of the relative minor in four notes before a solo clarinet plays the second theme in that relative minor's parallel key, then passes it to a solo oboe. An allegro moderato theme opening (read slowly, with pauses) “G low D G F-sharp G F A” is played by the cellos in this symphony's first movement. That movement's first theme begins with two repetitions of a slurred “dotted half, dotted quarter, eighth eighth eighth” figure on oboe and clarinet. Either a “Philosopher's Scherzo” and “March of Destiny” by August Ludwig, or Brain Newbould's suggestion of edits made from the B minor entr'acte from the composer's incidental music to Rosamunde, are sometimes added to this piece. For 10 points, name this numerical predecessor to the composer's “Great C minor” symphony, a B minor composition by Franz Schubert whose scherzo is incomplete.
tossups.answer: The Unfinished Symphony [or Franz Schubert's Symphony No. 8 in B minor; or D 759; accept 8 or Eighth after “Schubert” is read]  <Arts Music - Smith>

tossups.question: By summing over position-dependent phase factors multiplied by functions with this property, one can construct Wannier wavefunctions. Physical systems with this property can be analysed using Floquet (flo-KAY) matrices, and Born-von Karman boundary conditions enforce this property. When working in quantum systems with this property, the nearly-free-electron and tight-binding models can be used to study electronic band structure. The Kronig-Penney model is one of the simplest non-trivial systems with this property. In potentials with this property, wavefunctions can be split into an exponential term and a term with this property, according to Bloch's theorem. For some value 'a', potentials with this property satisfy the equation 'V of x plus a' equals 'V of x.' For 10 points, what property of crystals means that their structures repeat in space?
tossups.answer: periodic [or periodicity; prompt on things like “being a crystal structure” by asking “what property do crystals necessarily have?”]  <Science Physics - Krol>

tossups.question: In January 2019, the leader of this party was denied permission to land his helicopter in a region controlled by the rival TMC. The largest general strike in history targeted this party's privatization policies in 2016. Supporters of this party identify themselves online with a word translating as “watchman”. This party has lodged complaints about the citizenship status of its chief opponent due to his Italian mother, Sonia This party gained popularity in 2019 after a series of “surgical strike” military actions. This party, which is often referred to by its official color, saffron, has ties to the extremist RSS. The current leader of this party was banned from traveling to the US due to his supervision of anti-Muslim pogroms as chief minister of Gujarat. For 10 points, name this party that promotes the ideology of Hindutva and is led by Narendra Modi.
tossups.answer: Bharatiya Janata Party [accept Bharatiya Janata]  <Current Events Non-US - Myers>

tossups.question: Drawing on Epictetus, al-Kindi likened this concept to the passengers of a boat who are left on an island. In another work, al-Kindi states that this concept resides “in the light of the creator” if it is directed to the pursuit of the intellect. According to al-Farabi, this concept serves as the formal, efficient, and final cause. In a commentary on Aristotle's work on this concept, Averroes argued that this concept is constructed from a hierarchy of faculties such as the “nutritive” and “perceptual.” In the Book of Healing, Avicenna argued for the existence of this concept with the example of a man suspended in the air with no sensory input who still affirms his own existence. That is the floating man thought experiment. For 10 points, name this concept, which Aristotle said was the animating essence of all living things in De Anima.
tossups.answer: the soul [accept spirit]  <RMP Philosophy/Thought - McLain>

tossups.question: In 1480, Thomas Croft and John Jay sent a ship to search for the sources of this commodity, which they believed to be an island called Hy-Brasil. According to New England folklore, Satan burned two black lines with his thumb and forefinger into this commodity as it escaped from his hands. A dispute over this commodity was forcibly ended when Eric of Pomerania' officials were arrested by the British. The murder of John the Broad in Grindavik led to one military conflict over this commodity. That conflict developed into a “war” named for this commodity between Britain and Iceland. Basque merchants profited from their discovery of extraordinarily rich sources of this commodity in Newfoundland's Grand Banks. This commodity was preserved by salting to supply Catholic demand during feast days on which eating meat was forbidden. For 10 points, name this fish that names a New England Cape.
tossups.answer: cod [prompt on fish before mention, accept haddock]  <History European 1400-1914 - Jankov>

tossups.question: In one poem, an author from this country wrote “Behold the Christ who flies higher than aviators / He holds the world's record for altitude.” That author from this country repeated the lines “comes the night sounds the hour / The days go by I endure” in a poem dedicated to a bridge. The enigmatic last line of a poem from this country has been variously translated as “sun corseless head” and “sun slit throat.” A technique in which different people each write one line of a poem called “exquisite corpse” originated in this country. An author from this country published the poem “Zone” in his collection Alcools. An author from this country defined the title concept as “psychic automatism in its purest state” in his first Surrealist Manifesto. For 10 points, name this home country of Guillaume Apollinaire and André Breton.
tossups.answer: France <Literature European - French>

tossups.question: While across the street from this building, Alfred Baldwin was distracted by the movie Attack of the Puppet People and did not see a police car pulling up. Men in this building may have been looking for evidence that future NBA commissioner Larry O'Brien was aware of an opponent's crooked dealings with Howard Hughes. After Frank Wills noticed pieces of duct tape on a door lock in this building, he called the police. Egil Krogh led a team involved in suppressing information about events in this building, and Bernard Barker met his partner in events at this building, E. Howard Hunt, while the two were planning the Bay of Pigs Invasion together. James McCord and four “Cuban freedom fighters” were arrested for committing crimes in this building, an incident later linked to G. Gordon Liddy and the White House “plumbers.” For 10 points, name this office building where burglars broke in and bugged the DNC headquarters in 1972.
tossups.answer: Watergate Office Building [or Watergate Complex; accept Watergate Hotel]  <History American (1945-present) - Cheyne>

tossups.question: Description Acceptable. According to a hadith in Sahih al-Bukhari, Muhammad kept reciting the Talbiyah prayer nonstop until he performed this action. Preparation for this action caused a stampede in 2006 that killed 346 people. The day before performing this action, people travel to the city of Muzdalifah to collect items that will be used to perform it. People sacrifice an animal and shave their heads following this action which occurs in the city of Mina. This event, which occurs on the 10th day of Dhu al-Hijjah, involves three jamarāt, or pillars, which represent a certain figure tempting Ibrahim to disobey Allah and preserve Ishmael. For 10 points, identify this event celebrated on Eid al-Adha, the third day of the Hajj, which typically involves 49 rocks.
tossups.answer: stoning of the Devil [accept Shaitan for “Devil” and reasonable descriptions for “stoning” including anything indicating people throwing rocks; accept ramy al-jamarāt before “jamarat”]  <RMP Non-Christian/Bible Religion - Hijazi>

tossups.question: This thinker posited that certain vacuum activities can occur in the absence of a sign stimulus. Like his teacher Oskar Heinroth, this thinker described the triumph ceremony as an example of ritualized behavior. In one book, this thinker described how a “zick-ceremony” helps to create a dominance hierarchy among jackdaws. With an alphabetically later collaborator, this scientist coined the term “innate releasing mechanism” and demonstrated the hawk/goose effect, in which young birds became agitated by the silhouettes of short-necked birds. This scientist worked with Niko Tinbergen to describe the fixed action pattern that underlies egg retrieval in graylag geese, several of which follow him in a famous photograph. King Solomon's Ring was written by, for 10 points, what ethologist known for his studies of imprinting?
tossups.answer: Konrad Lorenz <Science Biology - Kothari>

tossups.question: A district court ruled that one of these measures “fairly administered is not rendered invalid by the evil motives of its draftsmen” in a case pursued by Jessie Butler. Two attempts to abolish or reduce this policy in Virginia were torpedoed in 1938 and 1948 by the Byrd Machine. In 1942, the Geyer Bill, which sought to outlaw these measures, passed the House but was filibustered in the Senate. These measures were held to be constitutional in the 1937 case Breedlove v Suttles. The 1966 Supreme Court case Harper v. Virginia Board of Elections ruled that these things were illegal at the state level. Alongside literacy tests, these measures were frequently subject to grandfather clauses which prevented poor whites from being disenfranchised. For 10 points, the 24th Amendment outlawed which tax measures which people had to pay in order to vote?
tossups.answer: poll tax [prompt on tax or on descriptive answers suggesting measures to disenfranchize African-Americans]  <History American (1865-1945) - Jackson>

tossups.question: A painting by this artist inspired Bernard Langlais's (“Lang-lee's”) wooden sculpture of a woman with logs for arms titled Local Girl. That woman is seen only from behind in a painting by this artist titled for the wood stove that dominates the room. This artist represented a model as one of the two weather-beaten doors in a painting also titled for the model's brother Alvaro. This artist depicted a boy running down a barren hill in one of his paintings set at the Kuerner farm. Sunlight flooding in from an open window lights a naked woman on a stool in this artist's painting Lovers, one of his many portraits of his neighbor Helga Testorf. The Farnsworth Art Museum operates a wooden house in Cushing, Maine that appears in the background of a painting by this artist in which the title girl wears a pink dress and crawls along the grass. For 10 points, name this realist painter of Christina's World.
tossups.answer: Andrew Wyeth <Arts Painting - Bentley>

tossups.question: One 1859 play set in one of these places had its original British ending changed for American audiences because it depicted a happy interracial marriage. That play climaxes with the Indian Wahnotee shooting the corrupt owner of one of these places and is titled for the mixed-race girl Zoe. That play set in one of these places is the most famous work of Dion Boucicault. In another play, the firm of Ambler & Ambler confiscates one of these places from its original owners. In one play, Oscar marries Birdie to acquire one of these places, and her desire to possess a mill built in one of these locations leads Regina Giddens to allow Horace to die of a heart attack. The loss of one of these places, Belle Reve, leads Blanche DuBois to move to New Orleans in A Streetcar Named Desire. For 10 points, name these places, one of which is used to grow cotton in The Little Foxes.
tossups.answer: plantations [prompt on house or similar answers with “in what kind of place?”]  <Literature American - Myers>

tossups.question: After her capture as a war prize, Manto escaped and bore Ocnus with this god. A son of Hermes founded Pallatinum along the domain of this god, where Canens committed suicide after Picus was turned into a woodpecker. A snake sacred to Asclepius crawled out of a ship and disappeared on an island that shares its name with this god. Claudia Quinta legendarily dragged a statue of Cybele through the domain personified by this god, which was formerly known as Albula. With the nymph Camasene, Janus fathered this god, who advised Aeneas to ally himself with Evander and the Arcadians. After ordering his soldiers to destroy the Pons Sublicius, Horatius Cocles legendarily jumped into the river personified by this god. Rhea Silvia placed the infants Romulus and Remus in a basket along, for 10 points, what deified Italian river along which Rome was founded.
tossups.answer: Tiber River [or Tiberinuns]  <RMP Greek/Roman Myth - Rao - Pothuraju>

tossups.question: A song that is sung in this city laments “Wasn't it good / Wasn't it fine / Isn't it madness he can't be mine” since “I Know Him So Well.” The contrasting lines “I can feel an angel sliding up to me” and “I can feel the devil walking next to me” are in a song titled for this city, which references Yul Brynner's longtime role in another musical set in this city. Jerome Robbins was inspired by khon and piphat music to create a ballet within a musical set in this city called “The Small House of Uncle Thomas.” “A Puzzlement” is sung in this city by a man who is fond of saying “etcetera, etcetera.” One woman sings “I Whistle a Happy Tune” to her son Louis upon arriving in this city. A song from Chess is titled for “One Night in [this city],” which is also the setting of a musical about Anna Leonowens's time teaching the children of Mongkut. For 10 points, The King and I is set in what capital of Siam?
tossups.answer: Bangkok, Thailand [accept Krung Thep or Bangkok, Siam]  <Arts Ballet/Dance/Musicals - Smith>

tossups.question: Platinum (II) chloride catalyzes a scheme in which the interaction between these two elements is altered in the Shilov system. A reaction which acts upon interactions between these two elements is performed using transition metal complexes with a d0 configuration and is known as sigma-bond metathesis. Stellar UV radiation creates a compound containing these two elements which is also thought to be an intermediate in the Fischer-Tropsch process, the methylidyne radical. MMO catalyzes the oxidation of the bond between these two elements. Transition metals interacting with a bond between these two elements form a three-center two-electron bond in an agostic interaction. Since bonds between these two elements are unreactive, they are often cleaved using a transition metal catalyst and replaced in a process known as activation. For 10 points, name these two elements found in benzene.
tossups.answer: carbon and hydrogen [or C and H, prompt on partial answer]  <Science Chemistry - Rombro>

tossups.question: This leader established a commission of professors called the Inquiry to study the demography of Europe. This leader ignored, or possibly never received, a letter sent on behalf of the “Group of Annamite Patriots” to him. This leader used his advisor, Edward House, to carry messages to and from European leaders. One of this leader's signature plans, which used the slogan “open covenants openly arrived at”, was attacked with the quip “God had his ten commandments and we broke them”. This leader promulgated a document that called for freedom of navigation through the Dardanelles and the establishment of a Polish state and a League of Nations. For 10 points, name this leader who made up part of the “Big Four” at the Paris Peace Conference along with David Lloyd George, Vittorio Orlando, and Georges Clemenceau, a position from which he issued the Fourteen Points.
tossups.answer: (Thomas) Woodrow Wilson <History European 1914-present - Myers>  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: Hyperfine coupling can be probed by an extension of this technique known as ENDOR. For 10 points each:
answer: EPR spectroscopy [or ESR spectroscopy; accept but do not reveal electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy or electron spin resonance spectroscopy]
parts: Name this technique, which exploits Zeeman splitting by varying the magnetic field until the difference between an electron's two possible energy levels is equal to the energy of photons emitted by the apparatus. This technique uses the g-factor analogously to how NMR uses chemical shift.
EPR Spectroscopy is often used after spin trapping to detect and classify these highly reactive molecules, which have an unpaired electron.
Free radicals can be detected by EPR spectroscopy because they have this property. Molecular Orbital theory correctly predicts that O2 has this property rather than its opposite.

bonuses.leadin: This piece, which premiered in the Carnegie Chapter Hall, was one of the first written for an ensemble containing only percussion. For 10 points each:
answer: I Ching [or Yi Jing; prompt on translations such as Classic of Changes or Book of Changes]  <Arts Music - Smith>
parts: Name this percussion piece in which changes within rhytmic cells mirror a scientific phenomenon. This Futurist-inspired piece by Edgard Varese calls for a field drum and a lion's roar.

Several pieces by Varese, including Arcana, make use of one of these phrases, distinguished from a Wagnerian concept by the fact that they are not transposed. In a symphony, one of these “obsessive” phrases represents English actress Harriet Smithson.
Varese's student Chou Wen-chung used this book for “mature period” pieces like Cursive. John Cage's Music of Changes was composed with the help of this Chinese fortune-telling book.

bonuses.leadin: In The Closing of the American Mind, Allan Bloom criticized the relativism of these institutions. For 10 points each:
answer: The Coddling of the American Mind: How Good Intentions and Bad Ideas Are Setting Up a Generation for Failure
parts: Name these institutions, whose use of “safe spaces” and “speech codes” was questioned in a 2018 book. These institutions' ranking by the US News & World Report has been criticized for overemphasizing research expenditures.

That 2018 book by Greg Lukianoff and Jonathan Haidt argues that changes in parenting styles and the explosion of social media usage have lead to a culture of “safetyism” on college campuses. This book advocates for the use of CBT techniques to combat cognitive distortions such as the myth of fragility and emotional reasoning.

The Coddling of the American Mind argues that the social form of this concept will only be achievable if it is framed in ways that appeal to the intuitive form. In an essay titled “this concept as Fairness,” another thinker divided this concept into the principles of liberty and equality.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the Church's influence on post-independence Irish politics. For 10 points each:
answer: Eamon de Valera [prompt on partial surname]
parts: After independence in Ireland, the church was authorized to place unwed mothers and prostitutes in these institutions named for a biblical figure at which they performed slave labor for attached abbeys.

This long-serving Irish leader both wrote, in 1937, and repealed, in 1973, article 44 of the Irish constitution, which acknowledged the church's “special position” in Irish society. This leader of Fianna Fail served 4 separate terms as Ireland's leader.

The Church blocked and campaigned against the repeal of Article 9 of the Irish constitution for decades. Article 9, which banned this practice, was struck down by a referendum in 2018. This practice's legality is protected by Roe v. Wade in the United States.

bonuses.leadin: This novel's Darlington Hall is the site of failed appeasement talks before World War II where the American Senator Lewis calls Lord Darlington an “amateur” in politics. For 10 points,
answer: Junior Ganymede Club  <Literature British Non-Shakespeare - Santanam>
parts: Name this novel where the narrator, Stevens, sets out in his employer's automobile to visit a former crush, Mrs. Benn, in Cornwall after receiving a letter from her.
The narrator Stevens works in this profession in Ishiguro's The Remains of the Day. Another character with this profession named Jeeves was created by P.G. Wodehouse.
In Wodehouse's stories, Jeeves belongs to this club where all members must record the foibles of their employers to forewarn other butlers and valets.

bonuses.leadin: This film extensively features the director's wife Geeta on such songs as “Hum Aapki Aankhon Mein,” which was added to appease distributors at the last minute. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this film in which director Guru Dutt plays the poet Vijay. Johnny Walker plays Abdul, who helps Vijay escape a mental asylum in this film.
Guru Dutt's films are often considered part of the parallel cinema movement, which was “parallel” to this popular industry of Hindi-Urdu films. This industry is based in Mumbai.

Parallel cinema directors Satyajit Ray and Bimal Roy were heavily inspired by this “Golden Age” Italian film movement. This movement is exemplified by the films of Roberto Rossellini and Vittorio De Sica.

bonuses.leadin: The Banach-Tarski paradox is a consequence of the fact that the group of isometries in three dimensions has a subgroup with this property that is generated by two elements. For 10 points each:
answer: group homomorphism [do NOT accept “homeomorphism”; ask them to spell it if there's any uncertainty]
integers [do not accept or prompt on “whole numbers”]  <Science Math - Morrison>
parts: Name this property of a group for which there is no nontrivial way to form the identity element out of the generators of the group. Any finitely-generated abelian group can be written as a torsion group times a group with this property.

Since every group has a set of generators, any group can be written as the image of a free group under one of these maps. A function phi between two groups is one of these maps if phi of “g times h” equals “phi of g” times “phi of h” for all g and h.

Up to isomorphism, the unique free group generated by a single element is this set under addition. This set, typically written Z, consists of all positive and negative numbers with no fractional part.

bonuses.leadin: The speaker of this poem describes a “common farmer” he knew who was “the father of five sons, and in them the fathers of sons, and in them the fathers of sons.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poem, whose fifth section is a discussion of the female form. The speaker of this poem claims that “the armies of those I love engirth me, and I engirth them.”
“I Sing the Body Electric” remained untitled until the title line was added in the 1867 republication of this collection, the most famous work of Walt Whitman.

The ninth section of “I Sing the Body Electric” catalogues various parts and sensations of the body before declaring, in the poem's final line, that they are this thing. In the second stanza of “Song of Myself,” the speaker claims to “loafe and invite” this thing.

bonuses.leadin: This leader issued an anti-bureaucratic manifesto that doubled as a declaration of war against the sultan of Gobir, Yunfa, after Yunfa took Muslim prisoners-of-war. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this cleric and war leader who was succeeded by his son, Muhammad Bello, who appointed himself the first ruler of a new caliphate.

dan Fodio and other radical clerics made up the administration of the Sokoto caliphate, which switched its language of administration from Arabic to this local language after his death. Emirs in cities like Kano and Maiduguri are important leaders among speakers of this language, who would later clash with Igbo and Yoruba during the Census Crisis.

The states established by dan Fodio and other reformers such as Umar Tall are often named for this concept from Islamic theology, often translated as “struggle” or “holy war”, since they often couched their attacks on established rulers in terms of this concept.

bonuses.leadin: Genesis 36 lists the kings of this country, while David and Joab defeated this kingdom at the Valley of Salt. For 10 points each:
answer: Kingdom of Edom [or Edomites; accept Seir]
his birthright [accept descriptive answers indicating the right to be recognized as the firstborn; accept bekorah]  <RMP Christian/Bible Religion - Suh>
parts: Name this kingdom located to the south of Judah and Moab. Obadiah and Ezekiel criticized this kingdom for being complicit in the destruction of Judah.

The Hebrew word Edom means red, which derives from the name of the kingdom's founder Esau, who was the red-haired older brother of this patriarch of the Israelites. This man's sons included Reuben and Joseph.

In order to satisfy his hunger after a long day of hunting, Esau foolishly exchanged this privilege for some stew that his brother Jacob had cooked, thus originating the expression “a mess of pottage.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about founding figures in linguistic subdisciplines who were active in the early 1970s and aren't Noam Chomsky. For 10 points each,
answer: women [accept Language and Woman's Place]  <Social Science Linguistics/Languages - Myers>
parts: This UCLA logician provided the starting point for modern semantic theory in his paper “English as a Formal Language”, which argued for analyzing natural languages similarly to programming languages.

This “father of sociolinguistics” founded that field with a series of influential studies on dialectical variations within New York department stores and on African-American Vernacular English speakers in Harlem.

Robin Lakoff pioneered a discipline of linguistics focused on these people with a book titled Language and [these people]'s Place. She argued in that book that patriarchal power structures lead these people to employ techniques of “powerless speech”.

bonuses.leadin: In speaking about one of these animals, a man shouts “Damn it, how he nicks 'em!” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this animal which bites a man's hip in a cartoon, prompting the victim to scream “Oh! This cursed Ograbme (oh-grab-me)!” General George Meade was also nicknamed after an “old” one of these animals.

The turtle and “Ograbme” were used by the cartoonist to mock this 1807 law of the Jefferson presidency blocking trade with foreign nations, including Britain. This law superseded the Non-Intercourse Act.

Tensions between the U.S. and Britain mounted after the British ship Leopard fired on the Chesapeake, an American ship commanded by this man. Court-martialed after the incident, this man later killed Stephen Decatur in a duel.

bonuses.leadin: This author inserted the word “tra-la” at varying places to upset the rhythm of his poem “The Taxis.” For 10 points each:
answer: Spanish Civil War <Literature British Non-Shakespeare - French>
parts: Name this author. Another poem by this author states “It's no go the Yogi-Man, it's no go Blavatsky / All we want is a bank balance and a bit of skirt in a taxi.”
MacNeice collaborated with this other poet on their travel book Letters from Iceland. This poet wrote “we must love one another or die” in his poem “September 1, 1939.”

Auden wrote “The stars are dead. The animals will not look” near the end of a poem about this event. Pablo Neruda wrote “Come and see the blood in the streets” in “I Explain a Few Things,” which is also about this event.

bonuses.leadin: The monk Nicolò Brancaleon came to this country to convert it to Catholicism but instead ended up introducing it to new painting techniques. For 10 points each:
answer: illuminated manuscript [accept illuminated gospels or illuminated bible; prompt on manuscript]  <Arts Painting - Myers>
parts: Name this country, home to painters such as Qes (kess) Adamu Tesfaw (TESS-fow). Artists from this country traditionally depict God as having three heads, and their cross sculptures feature intricate latticework.

Brancaleon's subject matter consisted primarily of icons of the Virgin Mary and this saint, who is also the namesake of the most elaborate church in the Lalibela complex. The eye of a storm aligns with this saint's weapon in a painting by Paolo Uccello.

One of the oldest known examples of Ethiopian art is one of these works named for Garima. The Limbourg Brothers' Book of Hours is also one of these works since it is decorated with detailed, miniature drawings.

bonuses.leadin: You are a member of a black family planning a driving vacation in the mid-20th century. Answer the following about some places you could go. For 10 points each:
parts: You might plan a vacation to this non-California state's all-black resort city of Idlewild, which was nicknamed “the black Eden” for its luxurious accommodations and racial tolerance. This state's towns of Climax and Royal Oak, however, are “sundown towns”, which do not allow non-whites within city limits after dark.

For a list of safe places to stay during your drive, you can consult a book named for this color. A mountain range named for this color runs through Vermont and contains safe hotels such as the Pales in Burlington.

You could also stay at one of the country's first black-owned hotels, this city's European Hotel, which was opened by Col. Wesley Redding in 1895 for a Cotton Exhibition in this city. While there, you could visit this city's historically black Morehouse College.

bonuses.leadin: Evidence of work with this material has been uncovered at Los Millares in Spain. For 10 points each:
answer: Corded Ware culture [or CWC]  <History European to 1400 - French>
parts: Name this material, which began to be worked at the end of the Neolithic period. The Chalcolithic period is sometimes named for this material.
Along with tin, copper is a component of this alloy. The Copper Age gave way to the age named for this alloy, which itself gave way to the Iron Age.
This Copper age culture occupied much of Northern and Eastern Europe until it was supplanted by the Beaker culture. This culture is named for the rope-like impressions on its pottery.

bonuses.leadin: The image of one of these things in the M87 galaxy was released in April 2019, and was made using an algorithm co-developed by Katie Bouman. For 10 points each:
answer: Kerr metric [do not accept Kerr-Newman metric]
parts: Name these entities studied by the Event Horizon Telescope. These objects have a singularity at their center and do not allow anything, even light, to escape them.

Observations of the M87 black hole were compared with theoretical predictions made using this metric. One of the four known exact solutions to the Einstein equations for black holes, this eponymous metric models black holes which have zero charge but are rotating.
Kerr black holes are theorized to possess these regions where either the Blandford-Znajek process or the penrose processs can occur to extract energy from their rotation.

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, Inger serves a prison sentence for killing her child after he was born with a hairlip. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this novel about the struggles of the peasant farmer Isak, who builds a prosperous farm with the help of Lensmand Geissler. This novel won its author the 1920 Nobel Prize in literature.
The author of Growth of the Soil and Hunger, Knut Hamsun, is from this country. The setting of Hunger, Christiania, is the old term for this country's capital city of Oslo.

In 1945, Knut Hamsun was arrested for treason in part for his publication of an obituary of this man that called him “a warrior for humankind and a preacher of the gospel of justice for all nations.” Another Norwegian author, Karl-Orve Knausgaard, wrote a six-volume autobiography named after a work by this man.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the morning star in various myth systems, for 10 points each:
answer: Eos [prompt on Dawn; do NOT accept or prompt on “Aurora”]
parts: This Aztec' god's heart became the morning star after he asked to be burned alive following a night of incest with his priestess sister. This feathered serpent god and brother of Xolotl used his blood to create the fifth race of man.

In Greek myth, Phosphorus is identified as the morning star; Homer calls this Titaness mother of Phosphorus “rosy-fingered” in the Iliad. This lover of Tithonus prayed to make him immortal but forgot to ask for youthfulness.

Shao Hao was the son of a god identified as Morning Star and a maiden who met by a tree bearing this type of fruit which grants immortality. Pyramus and Thisbe plan to meet by tree with this fruit; when Pyramus kills himself, his blood makes this fruit dark red.

bonuses.leadin: Traits of these organs, like SLA, have been used to define a fast-slow economic spectrum that defines the range of adaptations in these organs. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these organs whose palisade mesophyll cells are the primary sites of photosynthesis for most vascular plants.

Monsi and Saeki described the attenuation of light by leaves in a plant canopy using this law, which was developed in chemistry. They found that the extinction coefficient in this law varies with the leaf angle distribution.
Sessile leaves lack this feature, a thin stalk that connects the leaf to the body of a plant.

bonuses.leadin: Six children with “torturing faces with the vacancy of wide sunflowers” taunt a boy who claims to be afraid of the dark in this story. For 10 points each:
answer: Empire of Japan [accept Nippon]  <Literature British Non-Shakespeare - Shanmugam>
parts: Name this story that ends when a chandelier is lit and it is discovered that a boy has died of fear when his twin brother touched his face during a game of hide-and-seek in the dark.

This author of “The End of the Party” wrote about the Wormsley Common Gang destroying an old house in his short story “The Destructors.” This author wrote a novel set in the same city about the love between Maurice Bendix and Sarah Miles in World War II-era London.

Greene also wrote a short story titled for the “invisible gentlemen” from this country, short stories from which include “In a Grove” and “Hell Screen”, which were written by the namesake of a prize for fiction from this country, Ryanosuke Akutagawa.
